articles.headline: A Winding Trail for Mitch McConnell to Lead the Senate
articles.snippet: The inscrutable Senate minority leader, who hopes to be the next Senate majority leader, traveled rural Kentucky in his tough re-election campaign with a group of supporters including the singer Lee Greenwood.
articles.abstract: The inscrutable Senate minority leader, who hopes to be the next Senate majority leader, traveled rural Kentucky in his tough re-election campaign with a group of supporters including the singer Lee Greenwood.
articles.lead_paragraph: HYDEN, Ky. — Mitch McConnell, flanked by animal feed and a stuffed coyote, urged the small Republican crowd in Begley’s General Store here to beat the Democrats “like a drum” and “run up the score.”

articles.headline: Investigation Causes Citigroup to Cut Profit
articles.snippet: Citigroup startled investors with an announcement that it had to lower its profit by $600 million because of “rapidly-evolving regulatory inquiries and investigations.”
articles.abstract: Citigroup startled investors with an announcement that it had to lower its profit by $600 million because of “rapidly-evolving regulatory inquiries and investigations.”
articles.lead_paragraph: Six years after the financial crisis landed Wall Street in a thicket of legal troubles, the world’s biggest banks remain buffeted by a patchwork of international regulators and prosecutors.
articles.byline: By Michael Corkery, Peter Eavis and Ben Protess

articles.headline: Inflation? Deflation Is New Risk
articles.snippet: Some central banks, scarred from old battles with escalating prices, were slow to see their new, real problem.
articles.abstract: Some central banks, scarred from old battles with escalating prices, were slow to see their new, real problem.
articles.lead_paragraph: “Be very, very careful what you put into that head, because you will never, ever get it out.”

articles.headline: The Coming Out of Apple’s Tim Cook: ‘This Will Resonate’
articles.snippet: Mr. Cook, Apple’s chief executive, said the trade-off to his own privacy was worthwhile, if the disclosure that he is gay could help others.
articles.abstract: Mr. Cook, Apple’s chief executive, said the trade-off to his own privacy was worthwhile, if the disclosure that he is gay could help others.
articles.lead_paragraph: Tim Cook’s declaration on Thursday that “I’m proud to be gay” made him the first publicly gay chief executive of a Fortune 500 company. But Mr. Cook isn’t just any chief executive. And Apple isn’t any company. It’s one of the most profitable companies in the Fortune 500 and ranks No. 1 on the magazine’s annual ranking of the most admired companies.

articles.headline: Campaigning to Extend, or End, One-Party Rule
articles.snippet: The trend toward one-party control of statehouses has made the states a testing ground for party policies in an era of gridlock in Washington.
articles.abstract: The trend toward one-party control of statehouses has made the states a testing ground for party policies in an era of gridlock in Washington.
articles.lead_paragraph: AITKIN, Minn. — As he steps to front doors along the winding roads here in his rural House district, State Representative Joe Radinovich announces that he is there to introduce himself, and “in case you want to yell at me about something.”

articles.headline: Liberia’s Ebola Crisis Puts President in Harsh Light
articles.snippet: As Liberia’s first elected leader after a devastating civil war, President Ellen Johnson Sirleaf has pushed the country to economic growth, but gains have been halted by the Ebola outbreak.
articles.abstract: As Liberia’s first elected leader after a devastating civil war, President Ellen Johnson Sirleaf has pushed the country to economic growth, but gains have been halted by the Ebola outbreak.
articles.lead_paragraph: MONROVIA, Liberia — The president waited until her family members were seated around the dining table before announcing, with no fanfare, the latest defection from her cabinet.

articles.headline: Japan Abruptly Acts to Stimulate Economy
articles.snippet: The unexpected move by the Bank of Japan helped send stocks higher around the world.
articles.abstract: The unexpected move by the Bank of Japan helped send stocks higher around the world.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Japan is opting for another round of shock treatment, in a stark admission that the country’s economic revival plan is faltering.

articles.headline: Luck Played Role in Discovery of Data Breach at JPMorgan Affecting Millions
articles.snippet: The bank was able to identify intruders on its network by looking for digital fingerprints seen on a trove of stolen data uncovered elsewhere.
articles.abstract: The bank was able to identify intruders on its network by looking for digital fingerprints seen on a trove of stolen data uncovered elsewhere.
articles.lead_paragraph: When it comes to defending a large company against an online attack, sometimes luck and timing can mean as much as spending hundreds of millions of dollars a year on computer security.
articles.byline: By Matthew Goldstein and Nicole Perlroth

articles.headline: Repeal of Health Law, Once Central to G.O.P., Is Side Issue in Campaigns
articles.snippet: In a year that was supposed to be dominated by attacks on the Affordable Care Act, few Republican candidates focused on repeal or offered alternatives.
articles.abstract: In a year that was supposed to be dominated by attacks on the Affordable Care Act, few Republican candidates focused on repeal or offered alternatives.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In early October, with his poll numbers stubbornly lagging his Democratic opponent’s, Ed Gillespie did something almost no other Republican candidate has done this campaign season. Mr. Gillespie — a former lobbyist, former chairman of the Republican National Committee and now Senate candidate in Virginia — unveiled a plan to replace the Affordable Care Act.
